captions.text: Today we're going to learn how to ollie.
We're going to take this in a few steps.
The first thing that people usually do
When they're learning how to ollie
Is they go and find a good crack.
So go find a crack
Put your back wheels in the crack.
This just helps to steady your board
So you're not rolling around everywhere.
Now the second thing is your foot position.
Your front foot is going to be slanted
On the board like this sideways.

And your back foot is going to be on your
tail
With the ball of your foot at the edge.
So your front foot is sideways

And your back foot is with the ball of your
foot on the tail.
Now the first thing is popping your tail.

This is the first of the three steps to the
ollie.
Popping your tail just like that.
So get used to that for a minute
And then get ready to do the second step

Which is going to be sliding your foot up
the board.

I want you to pay special attention to the
knee
And look at how the knee moves

To make that foot slide in the direction like
that.
This is what gives you your lift
And really what makes the entire ollie happen.
So after you pop your tail
You're going to slide your foot up.

The most important thing to learning how to
ollie

Is getting the timing correct between these
two parts.
Part 1 right here and part 2, that slide.
It's almost simultaneous
But you really have to get that action
Between those two steps down.

Now the third step is just putting your feet
down
On the bolts and landing.
It's pretty simple, self-explanatory.
So you get that step 1 and that step 2 down
And then you're going to roll around
And just do ollies everywhere.
This is really a basic fundamental trick
And you're going to be doing it a lot

So you might as well get really good at it
now.
Go to braillskateboarding.com
Send me your best ollie attempt.
I'll do some voice-over on your video
And send it back to you
And see if I can help you out with your ollies.
Don't forget to subscribe for future videos.

title: HOW TO OLLIE THE EASIEST WAY TUTORIAL

got so frustrated because he was trying so hard to get it. He went inside 
and me and my other friend were still practising. I have been skating 
longer than both but I stopped for about 8 months when I hurt my foot so I 
had to kinda learn everything again. So me and my friend were doing okay 
but after a while I got it, my other friend came back out and I didnt tell 
him because he would get upset but he gets defensive when I try to show him 
what he is doing wrong. Do you think I should tell him I learned (maybe he 
will let me teach him) or just wait a while until he gets it and practice 
on my own﻿

comments.text:
You're likely not sliding too much, you're just not putting your foot back 
into place after the slide. Reme,ber that your foot should be perpendicular 
(horizontal) to the board. It should stop naturally around the nose if you 
don't force it.

perfrct it while moving. and is there a foot placement at your backfoot? 
like I know its suppose to be on the tail for the board to pop but where do 
you exactly put it to get more pop? My friend said to ollie higher is to 
jump. I tried it. I jumped but my board leaves me. it doesnt go with me. 
help amyone, please. ﻿
comments.author: Olive Torres

comments.text:
You use your back foot to jump right when your front foot slides to the 
nose and starts creating a coutner-force, and work on sliding your foot as 
parallel to the board as possible.

A crude way to think about it is like one person pushing up one side of a 
see-saw while the other one jumps in their seat, letting the see-saw follow 
them up.

comments.text:
to get your back wheels off the ground, make sure after you pop you are 
JUMPING and lifting your back foot STRAIGHT UP.  The slide will cause the 
board to "stick" to your back foot and complete the trick. Hope this helped 
a bit
